case_vignette: a 36-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled crohn's disease presents for evaluation of a painful non-healing wound on the left lower leg. patient endorses a pus bump developing on the left leg two months ago which he initially thought was a spider bite but eventually popped open. he was seen at urgent care a month ago and received one week course of cephalexin without any improvement. local debridement attempts at bedside by the urgent care provider resulted in significant expansion of the ulcer. physical examination reveals a well demarcated ovoid ulcer on the left distal shin with violaceous, rolled borders and cribriform base with yellow-red exudate.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful, non-healing wound on my left lower leg.
How long has the wound been present?
The wound has been present for two months.
Have you had similar wounds in the past?
No, I have not had similar wounds in the past.
Do you have any chronic diseases like diabetes or peripheral vascular disease?
Yes, I have a chronic disease called Crohn's disease, but not diabetes or peripheral vascular disease.
Have you been on any new medications or treatments recently for your Crohn's disease?
No, I have not been on any new medications or treatments recently for my Crohn's disease.
Does the wound show any signs of infection such as pus, increased redness, or odor?
Yes, the wound has pus and a yellow-red exudate.
Have you experienced any fever or chills in addition to the symptoms on your leg?
No, I have not experienced any fever or chills.
Final Diagnosis: Pyoderma gangrenosum
